Telephones and Tootise Pops

Aug 23, 2008

by Jonathan Clausen

This is a poem to my Grandmother, Vivian
who I have not called nor written on time
for most of these thirty-five years on this earth.
You’d wear purple someday,
that’s what a picture said.
Purple is nice.
Makes me think of popsicles, Tootsie pops too.
Grape soda is purple; so was the color
of pajamas you once bought me at Christmas.
I wanted the Dolphins, got Vikings instead,
but jammies were yearly and next year brought teal
and orange.

Purple’s also the color, of bruises I saw from a fall
you’d taken while no one was around you at all,
when last we visited.
You asked for more syrup, more sweetness, it seemed,
eyes stared toward some distance, you struggled to fight
the shake of your morning.
This vacant stare scared me, this I confess
I’m not ready, you see, yet know all too well
someday…

It’s from polio they say, a blight which once took
hold of your body, in the past, in your youth.
You beat it back then, though damage was done.
Today you are stronger, but weaker, it seems,
as you push yourself, still, in this race you must run.
The phone rings.

Who lives 85 years? That’s what Grandpa once said.
You planned a retirement, modest and yet
today you are older than you thought you could be.
The money is waning, the medicine wants.
Your home’s now with strangers.

“Hello, Grandma” I answer, warm and exuberant.
Salutations exchanged, pictures sent, and then
a cough from pneumonia.
You’ve beat it before; none of this causes worry.
I tease you, you laugh, tell me you must go.
It’s time for your dinner: farm cooking, no doubt.
Your nurse is approaching, just a little time left
for those few words which sum up quite clear
your person, your goodness, you say:

“I’m proud of you, Jon. God bless and I love you
too.”
